stem: Based on the patient's current assessment and lab values, what actions should the nurse prioritize?
options: increase the magnesium sulfate infusion rate
assess the patient's deep tendon reflexes
decrease the magnesium sulfate infusion rate
the patient is exhibiting signs of magnesium toxicity

blanks.correctOption: the patient is exhibiting signs of magnesium toxicity

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
1400: S: Patient reports feeling increasingly lethargic and 'out of it.' States, 'I feel like I can barely breathe.'
1405: B: Patient is a 28-year-old G1P0 at 34 weeks gestation, admitted for preeclampsia with severe features. Receiving magnesium sulfate at 2 grams/hour per protocol.
1410: A: Patient is somnolent. Respiratory rate is 10 breaths/min and shallow. Deep tendon reflexes are absent. Urine output has decreased to 20 mL/hr. Magnesium level is elevated. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows normal variability. 
1415: R: Suspect magnesium toxicity. Recommend discontinuing magnesium sulfate infusion and administering calcium gluconate per protocol. Continuous monitoring of respiratory status, deep tendon reflexes, and urine output is essential. Notify provider immediately.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Somnolent, difficult to arouse.
Neuro: Absent deep tendon reflexes (DTRs).
Resp: Shallow respirations, diminished breath sounds bilaterally.
CV: Regular heart rate, no murmurs.
GU: Foley catheter in place, urine output 20 mL/hr.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• Magnesium sulfate 2g/hr IV
  • Monitor vital signs every 15 minutes
  • Strict I&O
  • Assess DTRs hourly

rationale.correct: Magnesium toxicity is characterized by decreased respiratory rate, absent DTRs, decreased urine output, and elevated magnesium levels. Calcium gluconate is the antidote for magnesium toxicity and should be readily available for administration.
rationale.incorrect: The other options do not address the immediate danger of magnesium toxicity. Increasing the magnesium sulfate infusion would worsen the toxicity. Assessing DTRs is important, but not the priority. Notifying the provider is also important, but after preparing the antidote.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: Calcium gluconate is the antidote for magnesium sulfate toxicity. Preparing it ensures prompt treatment when magnesium toxicity is suspected.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: The patient's decreased respiratory rate, absent DTRs, and elevated magnesium level indicate magnesium toxicity, necessitating immediate intervention.

clinicalPearls: Magnesium toxicity can lead to respiratory arrest and cardiac arrest if left untreated.
Always have calcium gluconate readily available when administering magnesium sulfate.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing to notify the provider first seems logical, but it delays the immediate administration of the antidote.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize actions based on the immediate threat to the patient's life. In this case, the patient's respiratory compromise due to magnesium toxicity requires immediate intervention with calcium gluconate.

mnemonic.title: STOP Mg
mnemonic.expansion: S - Stop infusion, T - Tell provider, O - Oxygen, P - Push Calcium Gluconate
